590 - Bedford Road
pleasantville, New York
September 28, 1961
Dear Bill Harley,
You have heard from my friends on the ASA’s Social
Philosophy Committee about my plan for a luncheon panel
at the November Conference in Washington* I hope you are
going to be in town, and I want to tell you why I hope
you’ll join us in this.
I meant the question - "Who speaks for the Republic?” -
to refer to the very old, and lately very deadly, issue, on
which the UN is impaled again today: it it possible for men
to think (at least for an important part of the time) as
members of the Public, and in terms of the general interest;
or is K right, and "there are no neutrals”? Second, I want
to mix in that discussion men from liberal adult education
with men from educational broadcasting, who have faced that
issue in many forms. You know it well! Third, the question
is how the general interest gets reflected, encouraged, en-
ligh^tend, in the e ducational effort; and what obstacles we
face, what pressures we ourselves are subject to.
The other radio-TV people I have suggested are Henry
Alter, Boyer Jarvis, and (as a lay publicist) Willard Kip-
linger. Will you come along for the ride (and the lunch)?
If you’d like to talk about it, and if I can't get to Wash¬
ington before then, perhaps you'd let me know when you are
in New York and we could get a spot of time together.
HjOpejfqlly,
tr
Johii Walker Powell
Mr. William Harley
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
Dupont Circle Building
Connecticut Avenue NW
Washington, D. C.
